Violation_Type: Immigration violation based on ineligibility for refugee status
Legal_Issue: Whether opposition to China's one-child policy constitutes a well-founded fear of persecution
Application_Facts: Applicant claims forced abortion, fines, and confiscation of shrimp pool due to opposition to one-child policy
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Alleged enforcement of one-child policy including penalties
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on political opinion and membership in a particular social group
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Immigration Act
Assessment_Factor: Nature and severity of harm, credibility of claims, evidence of persecution
Procedural_Issue: Initial rejection by Refugee Board followed by application for judicial review
Credibility_Assessment: Claims of emotional distress and economic sanctions found insufficiently corroborated
Legal_Provision_Cited: Provisions relating to Convention refugee definition in the Immigration Act
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to resistance to state population control policy
Evidence_Assessed: Economic sanctions and emotional distress deemed insufficient to establish persecution
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee and protection from removal
Governing_Rule: A well-founded fear of persecution must be based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing physical harm or systemic persecution beyond economic penalties
Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Decisional_Body: Refugee Determination Division / Refugee Appeal Division
Harm_Assessment: No direct physical harm proven; only economic and emotional impacts alleged
Cause_Description: Applicant's opposition to China's one-child policy and alleged penalties imposed
Evidence_Handling: Board assessed credibility and sufficiency of evidence; court found no legal error
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; applicant failed to meet criteria under the Immigration Act
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient objective evidence to support allegations of persecution
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable â€“ claim based on fear of return, not residency violation
Legal_Provision: Section defining Convention refugee in the Immigration Act
Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of the Canadian immigration authorities and courts over refugee claims
Evidence_Assessment: Economic sanctions alone do not constitute persecution under international law
Decision_Rationale: Persecution requires more than financial penalty or emotional distress; no proof of targeted harm based on protected grounds
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of corroboration for serious allegations such as forced abortion
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on protected grounds under the 1951 Refugee Convention as incorporated in Canadian law
